Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: கண்ணோட்டம் இல்லவர் கண்ணிலர் கண்ணுடையார் கண்ணோட்டம் இன்மையும் இல்.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: Men without kind looks are men without eyes; those who (really) have eyes are also not devoid of kind looks.

Layered_Composition.Foreground: A split-screen portrait. On the left, a figure is shown with physically perfect but completely black, empty eye sockets, representing the 'eyeless' ('கண்ணிலர்') who lack benignity.
Layered_Composition.Midground: On the right, another figure is shown whose eyes are luminous, radiating a warm, compassionate golden light ('கண்ணோட்டம்'). These are the ones who truly 'have eyes' ('கண்ணுடையார்').
Layered_Composition.Background: The world as seen by the left figure is a dark, disconnected void. The world seen by the right figure is vibrant, interconnected, and full of life.

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: A direct, definitional statement: Benignity is the true function of the eye. Lacking it means being truly blind, while possessing it is the sign of true sight.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The empty sockets versus the luminous, light-giving eyes is the central, stark metaphor. This makes the abstract concept of 'kannottam' a tangible quality of sight.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The left side is dark, cold, and shadowed. The right side is illuminated by the warm, golden light emanating from the compassionate eyes.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A tight, symmetrical close-up on the two faces, forcing an immediate comparison.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, hyper-realistic, focusing on the texture and light of the eyes (or lack thereof).
Technical_Cues.Lighting: High-contrast, split lighting to match the theme.

Cultural_Anchors: Those lacking benignity are eyeless ('கண்ணோட்டம் இல்லவர் கண்ணிலர்')
Those with eyes possess benignity ('கண்ணுடையார் கண்ணோட்டம் இன்மையும் இல்')
Kindness as the essence of sight.
